∇𝐖lℒsubscript∇superscript𝐖𝑙ℒ\displaystyle\nabla_{\mathbf{W}^{l}}\mathcal{L}∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L =δl⁢(𝐚l−1)T,absentsuperscript𝛿𝑙superscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑙1T\displaystyle=\mathbf{\delta}^{l}(\mathbf{a}^{l-1})^{\mathrm{T}},= italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (4.A.3)
∇𝐛lℒsubscript∇superscript𝐛𝑙ℒ\displaystyle\nabla_{\mathbf{b}^{l}}\mathcal{L}∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L =δl.absentsuperscript𝛿𝑙\displaystyle=\mathbf{\delta}^{l}.= italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

The output layer’s error is simply given by

δL=∇𝐚Lℒ⊙σ′⁢(𝐧L),superscript𝛿𝐿subscript∇superscript𝐚𝐿direct-productℒsuperscript𝜎′superscript𝐧𝐿\mathbf{\delta}^{L}=\nabla_{\mathbf{a}^{L}}\mathcal{L}\odot\sigma^{\prime}(% \mathbf{n}^{L}),italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L ⊙ italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (4.A.4)

where ⊙direct-product\odot⊙ denotes the Hadamard element-wise product and σ′superscript𝜎′\sigma^{\prime}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the activation’s derivative with respect to its argument. Subsequent earlier layer’s error are computed with

δl=(𝐖l+1)T⁢δl+1⊙σ′⁢(𝐧l),l∈{1,⋯,L−1}.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝛿𝑙direct-productsuperscriptsuperscript𝐖𝑙1Tsuperscript𝛿𝑙1superscript𝜎′superscript𝐧𝑙𝑙1⋯𝐿1\displaystyle\mathbf{\delta}^{l}=(\mathbf{W}^{l+1})^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{\delta% }^{l+1}\odot\sigma^{\prime}(\mathbf{n}^{l}),\qquad l\in\{1,\cdots,L-1\}.italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊙ italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_l ∈ { 1 , ⋯ , italic_L - 1 } . (4.A.5)

A usual parameter update takes on the form

(𝐖l)new=𝐖l−β⁢∇𝐖lℒ,subscriptsuperscript𝐖𝑙newsuperscript𝐖𝑙𝛽subscript∇superscript𝐖𝑙ℒ(\mathbf{W}^{l})_{\text{new}}=\mathbf{W}^{l}-\beta\nabla_{\mathbf{W}^{l}}% \mathcal{L},( bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT new end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_β ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L , (4.A.6)

where β𝛽\betaitalic_β is a positive learning rate.

4.A.2 Proof: Permutation Equivalence

In the following appendix subsection, we show the permutation equivalence for feed-forward and convolutional layers.

Permutation Equivalence for Feed-forward Layers.

Consider the permutation matrix 𝐏l∈ℕNi×Nlsuperscript𝐏𝑙superscriptℕsubscript𝑁𝑖subscript𝑁𝑙\mathbf{P}^{l}\in\mathbb{N}^{N_{i}\times N_{l}}bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT × italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, such that (𝐏l)T⁢𝐏l=𝐈superscriptsuperscript𝐏𝑙Tsuperscript𝐏𝑙𝐈(\mathbf{P}^{l})^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{P}^{l}=\mathbf{I}( bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_I, where 𝐈𝐈\mathbf{I}bold_I is the identity matrix. We can write the weighted sum for layer l𝑙litalic_l as

𝐧l+1superscript𝐧𝑙1\displaystyle\mathbf{n}^{l+1}bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =𝐖l+1⁢𝐚l+𝐛l+1absentsuperscript𝐖𝑙1superscript𝐚𝑙superscript𝐛𝑙1\displaystyle=\mathbf{W}^{l+1}\;\mathbf{a}^{l}+\mathbf{b}^{l+1}= bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (4.A.7)
=𝐖l+1⁢σ⁢(𝐧l)+𝐛l+1absentsuperscript𝐖𝑙1𝜎superscript𝐧𝑙superscript𝐛𝑙1\displaystyle=\mathbf{W}^{l+1}\;\sigma(\mathbf{n}^{l})+\mathbf{b}^{l+1}= bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_σ ( bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=𝐖l+1⁢σ⁢(𝐖l⁢𝐚l−1+𝐛l)+𝐛l+1.absentsuperscript𝐖𝑙1𝜎superscript𝐖𝑙superscript𝐚𝑙1superscript𝐛𝑙superscript𝐛𝑙1\displaystyle=\mathbf{W}^{l+1}\;\sigma(\mathbf{W}^{l}\mathbf{a}^{l-1}+\mathbf{% b}^{l})+\mathbf{b}^{l+1}.= bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_σ ( bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

As 𝐏lsuperscript𝐏𝑙\mathbf{P}^{l}bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a permutation matrix and since we use the element-wise nonlinearity σ(.)\sigma(.)italic_σ ( . ), it holds that

𝐏l⁢σ⁢(𝐧l)=σ⁢(𝐏l⁢𝐧l),superscript𝐏𝑙𝜎superscript𝐧𝑙𝜎superscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐧𝑙\displaystyle\mathbf{P}^{l}\sigma(\mathbf{n}^{l})=\sigma(\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf% {n}^{l}),bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_σ ( bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_σ ( bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (4.A.8)

which implies that we can write

𝐧l+1superscript𝐧𝑙1\displaystyle\mathbf{n}^{l+1}bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =𝐖l+1⁢𝐈⁢σ⁢(𝐖l⁢𝐚l−1+𝐛l)+𝐛l+1absentsuperscript𝐖𝑙1𝐈𝜎superscript𝐖𝑙superscript𝐚𝑙1superscript𝐛𝑙superscript𝐛𝑙1\displaystyle=\mathbf{W}^{l+1}\;\mathbf{I}\;\sigma(\mathbf{W}^{l}\;\mathbf{a}^% {l-1}+\mathbf{b}^{l})+\mathbf{b}^{l+1}= bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I italic_σ ( bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (4.A.9)
=𝐖l+1⁢(𝐏l)T⁢𝐏l⁢σ⁢(𝐖l⁢𝐚l−1+𝐛l)+𝐛l+1absentsuperscript𝐖𝑙1superscriptsuperscript𝐏𝑙Tsuperscript𝐏𝑙𝜎superscript𝐖𝑙superscript𝐚𝑙1superscript𝐛𝑙superscript𝐛𝑙1\displaystyle=\mathbf{W}^{l+1}\;(\mathbf{P}^{l})^{\mathrm{T}}\;\mathbf{P}^{l}% \;\sigma(\mathbf{W}^{l}\;\mathbf{a}^{l-1}+\mathbf{b}^{l})+\mathbf{b}^{l+1}= bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_σ ( bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=𝐖l+1⁢(𝐏l)T⁢σ⁢(𝐏l⁢𝐖l⁢𝐚l−1+𝐏l⁢𝐛l)+𝐛l+1absentsuperscript𝐖𝑙1superscriptsuperscript𝐏𝑙T𝜎superscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐖𝑙superscript𝐚𝑙1superscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐛𝑙superscript𝐛𝑙1\displaystyle=\mathbf{W}^{l+1}\;(\mathbf{P}^{l})^{\mathrm{T}}\;\sigma(\mathbf{% P}^{l}\;\mathbf{W}^{l}\;\mathbf{a}^{l-1}+\mathbf{P}^{l}\;\mathbf{b}^{l})+% \mathbf{b}^{l+1}= bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_σ ( bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=𝐖^l+1⁢σ⁢(𝐖^l⁢𝐚l−1+𝐛^l)+𝐛l+1,absentsuperscript^𝐖𝑙1𝜎superscript^𝐖𝑙superscript𝐚𝑙1superscript^𝐛𝑙superscript𝐛𝑙1\displaystyle=\mathbf{\hat{W}}^{l+1}\;\sigma(\mathbf{\hat{W}}^{l}\;\mathbf{a}^% {l-1}+\mathbf{\hat{b}}^{l})+\mathbf{b}^{l+1},= over^ start_ARG bold_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_σ ( over^ start_ARG bold_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + over^ start_ARG bold_b end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where 𝐖^l+1=𝐖l+1⁢(𝐏l)Tsuperscript^𝐖𝑙1superscript𝐖𝑙1superscriptsuperscript𝐏𝑙T\mathbf{\hat{W}}^{l+1}=\mathbf{W}^{l+1}(\mathbf{P}^{l})^{\mathrm{T}}over^ start_ARG bold_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝐖^l=𝐏l⁢𝐖lsuperscript^𝐖𝑙superscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐖𝑙\mathbf{\hat{W}}^{l}=\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{W}^{l}over^ start_ARG bold_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝐛^l=𝐏l⁢𝐛lsuperscript^𝐛𝑙superscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐛𝑙\mathbf{\hat{b}}^{l}=\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{b}^{l}over^ start_ARG bold_b end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are the permuted weight matrices and bias vector.

Note that rows of weight matrix and bias vector of layer l𝑙litalic_l are exchanged together with columns of the weight matrix of layer l+1𝑙1l+1italic_l + 1. In turn, ∀l∈{1,⋯,L−1}for-all𝑙1⋯𝐿1\forall l\in\{1,\cdots,L-1\}∀ italic_l ∈ { 1 , ⋯ , italic_L - 1 }, (4.A.9) holds true. At any layer l𝑙litalic_l, there exist Nlsubscript𝑁𝑙N_{l}\!italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT different permutation matrices 𝐏lsuperscript𝐏𝑙\mathbf{P}^{l}bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, in total there are ∏l=1L−1Nl!superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑙1𝐿1subscript𝑁𝑙\prod_{l=1}^{L-1}\,N_{l}!∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ! equivalent networks.

Additionally, we can write

(𝐏l⁢𝐖l)new=subscriptsuperscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐖𝑙newabsent\displaystyle(\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{W}^{l})_{\text{new}}=( bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT new end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 𝐏l⁢𝐖l−α⁢𝐏l⁢∇𝐖lℒsuperscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐖𝑙𝛼superscript𝐏𝑙subscript∇superscript𝐖𝑙ℒ\displaystyle\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{W}^{l}\!-\alpha\mathbf{P}^{l}\nabla_{% \mathbf{W}^{l}}\mathcal{L}bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L (4.A.10)
=\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!== 𝐏l⁢𝐖l−α⁢𝐏l⁢δl⁢(𝐚l−1)Tsuperscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐖𝑙𝛼superscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝛿𝑙superscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑙1T\displaystyle\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{W}^{l}\!-\alpha\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{\delta% }^{l}(\mathbf{a}^{l-1})^{\mathrm{T}}bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!== 𝐏l⁢𝐖l−α⁢𝐏l⁢[(𝐖l+1)T⁢δl+1⊙σ′⁢(𝐧l)]⁢(𝐚l−1)Tsuperscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐖𝑙𝛼superscript𝐏𝑙delimited-[]direct-productsuperscriptsuperscript𝐖𝑙1Tsuperscript𝛿𝑙1superscript𝜎′superscript𝐧𝑙superscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑙1T\displaystyle\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{W}^{l}\!-\alpha\mathbf{P}^{l}\left[(\mathbf% {W}^{l+1})^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{\delta}^{l+1}\odot\sigma^{\prime}(\mathbf{n}^{l% })\right]\,(\mathbf{a}^{l-1})^{\mathrm{T}}bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ ( bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊙ italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ( bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!== 𝐏l⁢𝐖l−α⁢[(𝐖l+1⁢𝐏T)T⁢δl+1⊙σ′⁢(𝐏l⁢𝐧l)]⁢(𝐚l−1)Tsuperscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐖𝑙𝛼delimited-[]direct-productsuperscriptsuperscript𝐖𝑙1superscript𝐏TTsuperscript𝛿𝑙1superscript𝜎′superscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐧𝑙superscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑙1T\displaystyle\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{W}^{l}\!-\alpha\left[(\mathbf{W}^{l+1}% \mathbf{P}^{\mathrm{T}})^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{\delta}^{l+1}\odot\sigma^{\prime}% (\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{n}^{l})\right]\,(\mathbf{a}^{l-1})^{\mathrm{T}}bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α [ ( bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊙ italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ( bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!== 𝐏l⁢𝐖l−α⁢[(𝐖l+1⁢(𝐏l)T)T⁢δl+1⊙σ′⁢(𝐏l⁢𝐖l⁢𝐚l−1+𝐏l⁢𝐛l)]⁢(𝐚l−1)T.superscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐖𝑙𝛼delimited-[]direct-productsuperscriptsuperscript𝐖𝑙1superscriptsuperscript𝐏𝑙TTsuperscript𝛿𝑙1superscript𝜎′superscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐖𝑙superscript𝐚𝑙1superscript𝐏𝑙superscript𝐛𝑙superscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑙1T\displaystyle\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{W}^{l}\!-\alpha[(\mathbf{W}^{l+1}(\mathbf{P% }^{l})^{\mathrm{T}})^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{\delta}^{l+1}\odot\sigma^{\prime}(% \mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{W}^{l}\mathbf{a}^{l-1}+\mathbf{P}^{l}\mathbf{b}^{l})]\!(% \mathbf{a}^{l-1})^{\mathrm{T}}.bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α [ ( bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊙ italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ( bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

If we apply a permutation 𝐏lsuperscript𝐏𝑙\mathbf{P}^{l}bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to our update rule (equation 4.A.6) at any layer except the last, then using the above, we can express the gradient-based update as

(𝐖^l)new=𝐖^l−α⁢[(𝐖^l+1)T⁢δl+1⊙σ′⁢(𝐖^l⁢𝐚l−1+𝐛^l)]⁢(𝐚l−1)T⁢□subscriptsuperscript^𝐖𝑙newsuperscript^𝐖𝑙𝛼delimited-[]direct-productsuperscriptsuperscript^𝐖𝑙1Tsuperscript𝛿𝑙1superscript𝜎′superscript^𝐖𝑙superscript𝐚𝑙1superscript^𝐛𝑙superscriptsuperscript𝐚𝑙1T□\displaystyle(\mathbf{\hat{W}}^{l})_{\text{new}}=\mathbf{\hat{W}}^{l}-\alpha% \left[(\mathbf{\hat{W}}^{l+1})^{\mathrm{T}}\mathbf{\delta}^{l+1}\odot\sigma^{% \prime}(\mathbf{\hat{W}}^{l}\mathbf{a}^{l-1}+\mathbf{\hat{b}}^{l})\right]\,(% \mathbf{a}^{l-1})^{\mathrm{T}}\square( over^ start_ARG bold_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT new end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α [ ( over^ start_ARG bold_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊙ italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + over^ start_ARG bold_b end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] ( bold_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT □ (4.A.11)

The above implies that the permutations not only preserve the structural flow of information in the forward pass, but also preserve the structural flow of information during the update with the backward pass. That is we preserve the structural flow of information about the gradients with respect to the parameters during the backward pass through the feed-forward layers.

Permutation Equivalence for Convolutional Layers.

We can easily extend the permutation equivalence in the feed-forward layers to convolution layers. Consider the 2D-convolution with input channel 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}bold_x and O𝑂Oitalic_O output channels 𝐚s1=[𝐚1.𝐚O]subscript𝐚subscript𝑠1delimited-[]subscript𝐚1absentsubscript𝐚𝑂\mathbf{a}_{s_{1}}=[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{a}_{1}\\ .\\ \mathbf{a}_{O}\end{smallmatrix}]bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ROW start_CELL bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ]. We express a single convolution operation for the input channel 𝐱𝐱{\bf x}bold_x with a convolutional kernel 𝐊o,o∈{1,…,O}subscript𝐊𝑜𝑜1…𝑂{\bf K}_{o},o\in\{1,...,O\}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o ∈ { 1 , … , italic_O } as

𝐚o=subscript𝐚𝑜absent\displaystyle\mathbf{a}_{o}=bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 𝐛o+𝐊o⋆𝐱,o∈{1,⋯,O},subscript𝐛𝑜⋆subscript𝐊𝑜𝐱𝑜1⋯𝑂\displaystyle\mathbf{b}_{o}+\mathbf{K}_{o}\star\mathbf{x},o\in\{1,\cdots,O\},bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ bold_x , italic_o ∈ { 1 , ⋯ , italic_O } , (4.A.12)

where ⋆⋆\star⋆ denotes the discrete convolution operation.

Note that in contrast to the whole set of permutation matrices 𝐏lsuperscript𝐏𝑙{\bf P}^{l}bold_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (which were introduced earlier) now we consider only a subset that affects the order of the input channels (if we have multiple) and the order of the concatenation of the output channels.

We now show that changing the order of input channels does not affect the output if the order of kernels is changed accordingly.

The proof is similar to the permutation equivalence for the feed-forward layer. The difference here is that we take into account only the change in the order of channels and kernels. In order to prove permutation equivalence here it suffices to show that we can represent the convolution of multiple input channels by multiple convolution kernels in an alternative form, that is as matrix-vector operation.

To do so we first show that we can express the convolution of one input channel with one kernel to its equivalent matrix-vector product form. Formally, we have that

𝐚o=subscript𝐚𝑜absent\displaystyle\mathbf{a}_{o}=bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 𝐛o+𝐊o⋆𝐱=subscript𝐛𝑜⋆subscript𝐊𝑜𝐱absent\displaystyle\mathbf{b}_{o}+\mathbf{K}_{o}\star\mathbf{x}=bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ bold_x = 𝐛o+𝐑o⁢𝐱,subscript𝐛𝑜subscript𝐑𝑜𝐱\displaystyle\mathbf{b}_{o}+\mathbf{R}_{o}\mathbf{x},bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x , (4.A.13)

where 𝐑osubscript𝐑𝑜\mathbf{R}_{o}bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the convolution matrix. We build the matrix 𝐑osubscript𝐑𝑜\mathbf{R}_{o}bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in this alternative form (4.A.13) for the convolution operation from the convolutional kernel 𝐊osubscript𝐊𝑜{\bf K}_{o}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. 𝐑osubscript𝐑𝑜\mathbf{R}_{o}bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has a special structure (if we have 1D convolution then it is known as a circulant convolution matrix), while the input channel 𝐱𝐱{\bf x}bold_x remains the same. The number of columns in 𝐑osubscript𝐑𝑜\mathbf{R}_{o}bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equals the dimension of the input channel, while the number of rows in 𝐑osubscript𝐑𝑜\mathbf{R}_{o}bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equals the dimension of the output channel. In each row of 𝐑osubscript𝐑𝑜{\bf R}_{o}bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we store the elements of the convolution kernel. That is we sparsely distribute the kernel elements such that the multiplication of one row 𝐑o,jsubscript𝐑𝑜𝑗{\bf R}_{o,j}bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of 𝐑osubscript𝐑𝑜{\bf R}_{o}bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the input channel 𝐱𝐱{\bf x}bold_x results in the convolution output ao,jsubscript𝑎𝑜𝑗{a}_{o,j}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the corresponding position j𝑗jitalic_j at the output channel 𝐚osubscript𝐚𝑜{\bf a}_{o}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The convolution of one input channel by multiple kernels can be expressed as a matrix-vector operation. In that case, the matrix in the equivalent form for the convolution with multiple kernels over one input represents a block concatenated matrix, where each of the block matrices has the previously described special structure, i.e.,

𝐚s1=[𝐚1.𝐚O]=subscript𝐚subscript𝑠1delimited-[]subscript𝐚1absentsubscript𝐚𝑂absent\displaystyle\mathbf{a}_{s_{1}}=\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{a}_{1}\\ .\\ \mathbf{a}_{O}\end{smallmatrix}\right]=bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ROW start_CELL bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ] = [𝐛1.𝐛O]+[𝐑1.𝐑O]⁢𝐱=𝐛f+𝐑f⁢𝐱,delimited-[]subscript𝐛1absentsubscript𝐛𝑂delimited-[]matrixsubscript𝐑1absentsubscript𝐑𝑂𝐱subscript𝐛𝑓subscript𝐑𝑓𝐱\displaystyle\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{b}_{1}\\ .\\ \mathbf{b}_{O}\end{smallmatrix}\right]+\left[\begin{matrix}\mathbf{R}_{1}\\ .\\ \mathbf{R}_{O}\end{matrix}\right]\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}_{f}+{\bf R}_{f}\mathbf{% x},[ start_ROW start_CELL bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ] + [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] bold_x = bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x , (4.A.14)

where 𝐛f=[𝐛1.𝐛O]subscript𝐛𝑓delimited-[]subscript𝐛1absentsubscript𝐛𝑂\mathbf{b}_{f}=\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{b}_{1}\\ .\\ \mathbf{b}_{O}\end{smallmatrix}\right]bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ROW start_CELL bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ] and 𝐑f=[𝐑1.𝐑O]subscript𝐑𝑓delimited-[]matrixsubscript𝐑1absentsubscript𝐑𝑂{\bf R}_{f}=\left[\begin{matrix}\mathbf{R}_{1}\\ .\\ \mathbf{R}_{O}\end{matrix}\right]bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ].

In the same way the convolution of multiple input channels 𝐱1,…,𝐱Ssubscript𝐱1…subscript𝐱𝑆\mathbf{x}_{1},...,\mathbf{x}_{S}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by multiple kernels 𝐊1,…,𝐊Osubscript𝐊1…subscript𝐊𝑂{\bf K}_{1},...,{\bf K}_{O}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be expressed as a matrix vector operation. In that case, the matrix in the equivalent form for the convolution with multiple kernels over multiple inputs represents a block diagonal matrix, where each of the blocks in the block diagonal matrix has the previously described special structure, i.e.,

[𝐚s1.𝐚ss]=delimited-[]subscript𝐚subscript𝑠1absentsubscript𝐚subscript𝑠𝑠absent\displaystyle\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{a}_{s_{1}}\\ .\\ \mathbf{a}_{s_{s}}\end{smallmatrix}\right]=[ start_ROW start_CELL bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ] = [𝐛f.𝐛f]+[𝐑f𝟎…𝟎....𝟎…𝟎𝐑f]⁢[𝐱1.𝐱S]=[𝐛f.𝐛f]+𝐑⁢[𝐱1.𝐱S],delimited-[]subscript𝐛𝑓absentsubscript𝐛𝑓delimited-[]matrixsubscript𝐑𝑓0…0absentabsentabsentabsent0…0subscript𝐑𝑓delimited-[]subscript𝐱1absentsubscript𝐱𝑆delimited-[]subscript𝐛𝑓absentsubscript𝐛𝑓𝐑delimited-[]subscript𝐱1absentsubscript𝐱𝑆\displaystyle\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{b}_{f}\\ .\\ \mathbf{b}_{f}\end{smallmatrix}\right]+\left[\begin{matrix}\mathbf{R}_{f}&{\bf 0% }&...&{\bf 0}\\ .&.&.&.\\ {\bf 0}&...&{\bf 0}&\mathbf{R}_{f}\\ \end{matrix}\right]\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{x}_{1}\\ .\\ \mathbf{x}_{S}\end{smallmatrix}\right]=\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{b}_{f}% \\ .\\ \mathbf{b}_{f}\end{smallmatrix}\right]+{\bf R}\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf% {x}_{1}\\ .\\ \mathbf{x}_{S}\end{smallmatrix}\right],[ start_ROW start_CELL bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ] + [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL bold_0 end_CELL start_CELL … end_CELL start_CELL bold_0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL start_CELL . end_CELL start_CELL . end_CELL start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_0 end_CELL start_CELL … end_CELL start_CELL bold_0 end_CELL start_CELL bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] [ start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ] = [ start_ROW start_CELL bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ] + bold_R [ start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ] , (4.A.15)

where 𝐑=[𝐑f𝟎…𝟎....𝟎…𝟎𝐑f]𝐑delimited-[]matrixsubscript𝐑𝑓0…0absentabsentabsentabsent0…0subscript𝐑𝑓{\bf R}=\left[\begin{matrix}\mathbf{R}_{f}&{\bf 0}&...&{\bf 0}\\ .&.&.&.\\ {\bf 0}&...&{\bf 0}&\mathbf{R}_{f}\\ \end{matrix}\right]bold_R = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL bold_0 end_CELL start_CELL … end_CELL start_CELL bold_0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL start_CELL . end_CELL start_CELL . end_CELL start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_0 end_CELL start_CELL … end_CELL start_CELL bold_0 end_CELL start_CELL bold_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ], which we can also express as

𝐚=𝐛+𝐑⁢[𝐱1.𝐱S],𝐚𝐛𝐑delimited-[]subscript𝐱1absentsubscript𝐱𝑆\displaystyle\mathbf{a}=\mathbf{b}+{\bf R}\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{x}_% {1}\\ .\\ \mathbf{x}_{S}\end{smallmatrix}\right],bold_a = bold_b + bold_R [ start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ] , (4.A.16)

where 𝐚=[𝐚s1.𝐚ss]𝐚delimited-[]subscript𝐚subscript𝑠1absentsubscript𝐚subscript𝑠𝑠{\bf a}=\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{a}_{s_{1}}\\ .\\ \mathbf{a}_{s_{s}}\end{smallmatrix}\right]bold_a = [ start_ROW start_CELL bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ] and 𝐛=[𝐛f.𝐛f]𝐛delimited-[]subscript𝐛𝑓absentsubscript𝐛𝑓{\bf b}=\left[\begin{smallmatrix}\mathbf{b}_{f}\\ .\\ \mathbf{b}_{f}\end{smallmatrix}\right]bold_b = [ start_ROW start_CELL bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL . end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW ].

Note that the above equation has an equivalent form with equation (4.A.7), therefore, the previous proof is valid for the update with respect to hole matrix 𝐑𝐑{\bf R}bold_R. However, 𝐑𝐑{\bf R}bold_R has a special structure, therefore for the update of of each element in 𝐑𝐑{\bf R}bold_R, we can use the chain rule, which results in

∂f⁢(𝐑)∂Ri⁢j=𝑓𝐑subscript𝑅𝑖𝑗absent\displaystyle\frac{\partial f({\bf R})}{\partial R_{ij}}=divide start_ARG ∂ italic_f ( bold_R ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = ∑k∑l∂f⁢(𝐑)∂Rk⁢l⁢∂Rk⁢l∂Ri⁢j=T⁢r⁢[[∂f⁢(𝐑)∂𝐑]T⁢∂𝐑∂Ri⁢j].subscript𝑘subscript𝑙𝑓𝐑subscript𝑅𝑘𝑙subscript𝑅𝑘𝑙subscript𝑅𝑖𝑗𝑇𝑟delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-[]𝑓𝐑𝐑𝑇𝐑subscript𝑅𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\sum_{k}\sum_{l}\frac{\partial f({\bf R})}{\partial R_{kl}}\frac{% \partial R_{kl}}{\partial R_{ij}}=Tr\left[\left[\frac{\partial f({\bf R})}{% \partial{\bf R}}\right]^{T}\frac{\partial{\bf R}}{\partial R_{ij}}\right].∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ∂ italic_f ( bold_R ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG divide start_ARG ∂ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = italic_T italic_r [ [ divide start_ARG ∂ italic_f ( bold_R ) end_ARG start_ARG ∂ bold_R end_ARG ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG ∂ bold_R end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] . (4.A.17)

Replacing f⁢()𝑓f()italic_f ( ) by ℒℒ\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L in the above and using the update rule equation (4.A.6) gives us the update equation for Ri⁢jsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑗{R}_{ij}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Using similar argumentation and derivation that leads to equation (4.A.11) concludes the proof for permutation equivalence for a convolutional layer □□\square□

Empirical Evaluation.

We empirically confirm the permutation equivalence (see Figure 4.A.1). We begin by comparing the accuracies of permuted models (Figure 4.A.1 left). To that end, we randomly initialize model A𝐴Aitalic_A and train it for 10 epochs. We pick one random permutation and permute all epochs of model A𝐴Aitalic_A. For the permuted version A⁢p𝐴𝑝Apitalic_A italic_p we compute the test accuracy for all epochs. The test accuracy of model A𝐴Aitalic_A and A⁢p𝐴𝑝Apitalic_A italic_p lie on top of each other, so the permutation equivalence holds for the forward pass. To test the backward pass, we create model B𝐵Bitalic_B as a copy of A⁢p𝐴𝑝Apitalic_A italic_p at initialization and train for 10 epochs. Again, train and test epochs of A𝐴Aitalic_A and B𝐵Bitalic_B lie on top of each other, which indicates that the equivalence empirically holds for the backward pass, too.

To track how models develop in weight space, we compute the mutual ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distances between the vectorized weights (Figure 4.A.1 right). The distance between A𝐴Aitalic_A and A⁢p𝐴𝑝Apitalic_A italic_p, as well as between A𝐴Aitalic_A and B𝐵Bitalic_B is high and identical. Therefore, model A𝐴Aitalic_A is far away from models A⁢p𝐴𝑝Apitalic_A italic_p and B𝐵Bitalic_B. Further, the distance between A⁢p𝐴𝑝Apitalic_A italic_p and B𝐵Bitalic_B is small, confirming the backward pass equivalence. We attribute the small difference to numerical errors.

Further Weight Space Symmetries.

It is important to note that besides the symmetry used above, other symmetries exist in the model weight space, which changes the representation of a NN model, but not its mapping, e.g., scaling of subsequent layers with piece-wise linear activation functions  [40]. While some of these symmetries may be used as augmentation, these particular mappings only create equivalent networks in the forward pass, but different gradients and updates in the backward pass when back propagating. Therefore, we did not consider them in our work.

Appendix 4.B Downstream Tasks Additional Details

In this appendix section, we provide additional details about the downstream tasks that we use to evaluate the utility of the hyper-representations obtained by our self-supervised learning approach.

4.B.1 Downstream Tasks Problem Formulation

We use linear probing as a proxy to evaluate the utility of the learned hyper-representations, similar to [60].

We denote the training and testing hyper-representations as 𝐙t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscript𝐙𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛{\bf Z}_{train}bold_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝐙t⁢e⁢s⁢tsubscript𝐙𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{\bf Z}_{test}bold_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We assume that training 𝐭t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscript𝐭𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛{\bf t}_{train}bold_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and testing 𝐭t⁢e⁢s⁢tsubscript𝐭𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{\bf t}_{test}bold_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT target vectors are given. We compute the closed form solution 𝐫^^𝐫\hat{\bf r}over^ start_ARG bold_r end_ARG to the regression problem

(Q⁢1):𝐫^=arg⁡min𝐫⁡‖𝐙t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n⁢𝐫−𝐭t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n‖22,:𝑄1^𝐫subscript𝐫superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐙𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝐫subscript𝐭𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛22(Q1):\hat{\bf r}=\arg\min_{{\bf r}}\|{\bf Z}_{train}{\bf r}-{\bf t}_{train}\|_% {2}^{2},( italic_Q 1 ) : over^ start_ARG bold_r end_ARG = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_r - bold_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

and evaluate the utility of 𝐙t⁢e⁢s⁢tsubscript𝐙𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{\bf Z}_{test}bold_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by measuring the R2superscript𝑅2R^{2}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT score [168] as discrepancy between the predicted 𝐙t⁢e⁢s⁢t⁢𝐫^subscript𝐙𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡^𝐫{\bf Z}_{test}\hat{\bf r}bold_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_r end_ARG and the true test targets 𝐭t⁢e⁢s⁢tsubscript𝐭𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{\bf t}_{test}bold_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Note that by using different targets 𝐭t⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢nsubscript𝐭𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛{\bf t}_{train}bold_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in (Q⁢1)𝑄1(Q1)( italic_Q 1 ), we can estimate different 𝐫𝐫{\bf r}bold_r coefficients. This enables us to evaluate on different downstream tasks, including, accuracy prediction (Acc), epoch prediction (Eph) as proxy to model versioning, F-Score [57] prediction (Fc), learning rate (LR), ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularization (ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-reg), dropout (Drop) and training data fraction (TF). For these target values, we solve (Q⁢1)𝑄1(Q1)( italic_Q 1 ), but for categorical hyper-parameters prediction, like the activation function (Act), optimizer (Opt), and initialization method (Init), we train a linear perceptron by minimizing a cross-entropy loss [57]. Here, instead of R2superscript𝑅2R^{2}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT score, we measure the prediction accuracy.

4.B.2 Downstream Tasks Targets

In this appendix subsection, we give the details about how we build the target vectors in the respective problem formulations for all of the downstream tasks.

Accuracy Prediction (Acc).

In the accuracy prediction problem, we assume that for each trained NN model on a particular data set, we have its accuracy. Regarding the task of accuracy prediction, the value at⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,isubscript𝑎𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖a_{train,i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the training NN models represents the training target value tt⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,i=at⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,isubscript𝑡𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖subscript𝑎𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖t_{train,i}=a_{train,i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, while the value at⁢e⁢s⁢t,jsubscript𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑗a_{test,j}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the testing NN models represents the true testing target value tt⁢e⁢s⁢t,j=at⁢e⁢s⁢t,jsubscript𝑡𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑗subscript𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑗t_{test,j}=a_{test,j}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Generalization Gap Prediction (GGap).

In the generalization gap prediction problem, we assume that for each trained NN model on a particular data set, we have its train and test accuracy. The generalization gap represents the target value gi=at⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,i−at⁢e⁢s⁢t,isubscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑎𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖subscript𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑖g_{i}=a_{train,i}-a_{test,i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the training NN models, while gj=at⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,j−at⁢e⁢s⁢t,jsubscript𝑔𝑗subscript𝑎𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑗subscript𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑗g_{j}=a_{train,j}-a_{test,j}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the true target tt⁢e⁢s⁢t,j=gjsubscript𝑡𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑗subscript𝑔𝑗t_{test,j}=g_{j}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the testing NN models.

Epoch Prediction (Eph).

We consider the simplest setup as a proxy to model versioning, where we try to distinguish between NN weights and biases recorded at different epoch numbers during the training of the NNs in the model zoo. To that end, we assume that we construct the model zoo such that during the training of a NN model, we record its different evolving versions, i.e., the zoo includes versions of one NN model at different epoch numbers eisubscript𝑒𝑖e_{i}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Similarly to the previous task, our targets for the task of epoch prediction are the actual epoch numbers, tt⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,i=et⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,isubscript𝑡𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖subscript𝑒𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖t_{train,i}=e_{train,i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and tt⁢e⁢s⁢t,j=et⁢e⁢s⁢t,jsubscript𝑡𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑗subscript𝑒𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑗t_{test,j}=e_{test,j}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively.

F Score Prediction

(Fc). To identify more fine-grained model properties, we therefore consider the class-wise F score. We define the F score prediction task similarly as in the previous downstream task. We assume that for each NN model in the training and testing subset of the model zoo, we have computed F score [57] for the corresponding class with label c𝑐citalic_c that we denote as Ftrain,c,i and Ftest,c,j, respectively. Then we use Ftrain,c,i and Ftest,c,i as a target value tt⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,c,i=subscript𝑡𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑐𝑖absentt_{train,c,i}=italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =Ftrain,c,i in the regression problem and set tt⁢e⁢s⁢t,c,j=subscript𝑡𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑐𝑗absentt_{test,c,j}=italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t , italic_c , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =Ftest,c,j during the test evaluation.

Hyper-parameters Prediction.

We define the hyper-parameter prediction task identically as the previous downstream tasks. Where for continuous hyper-parameters, like learning rate (LR), ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularization (ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-reg), dropout (Drop), and nonlinear thresholding function (TF), we solve the linear regression problem (Q⁢1)𝑄1(Q1)( italic_Q 1 ). Similarly to the previous task, our targets for the task of hyperparameters prediction are the actual hyperparameters values.

In particular, for learning rate tt⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,i=l⁢e⁢a⁢r⁢n⁢i⁢n⁢g⁢ ⁢r⁢a⁢t⁢esubscript𝑡𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑙𝑒𝑎𝑟𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑟𝑎𝑡𝑒t_{train,i}=learning\text{ }rateitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_l italic_e italic_a italic_r italic_n italic_i italic_n italic_g italic_r italic_a italic_t italic_e, for ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularization tt⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,i=ℓ2⁢-⁢r⁢e⁢g⁢u⁢l⁢a⁢r⁢i⁢z⁢a⁢t⁢i⁢o⁢n⁢ ⁢t⁢y⁢p⁢esubscript𝑡𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖subscriptℓ2-𝑟𝑒𝑔𝑢𝑙𝑎𝑟𝑖𝑧𝑎𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛 𝑡𝑦𝑝𝑒t_{train,i}=\ell_{2}\text{-}regularization\text{ }typeitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_r italic_e italic_g italic_u italic_l italic_a italic_r italic_i italic_z italic_a italic_t italic_i italic_o italic_n italic_t italic_y italic_p italic_e, for dropout (Drop) tt⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,i=d⁢r⁢o⁢p⁢o⁢u⁢t⁢ ⁢v⁢a⁢l⁢u⁢esubscript𝑡𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑑𝑟𝑜𝑝𝑜𝑢𝑡 𝑣𝑎𝑙𝑢𝑒t_{train,i}=dropout\text{ }valueitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_d italic_r italic_o italic_p italic_o italic_u italic_t italic_v italic_a italic_l italic_u italic_e and for nonlinear thresholding function (TF) tt⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n,i=n⁢o⁢n⁢l⁢i⁢n⁢e⁢a⁢r⁢ ⁢t⁢h⁢r⁢e⁢s⁢h⁢o⁢l⁢d⁢i⁢n⁢g⁢ ⁢f⁢u⁢n⁢c⁢t⁢i⁢o⁢nsubscript𝑡𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑙𝑖𝑛𝑒𝑎𝑟 𝑡ℎ𝑟𝑒𝑠ℎ𝑜𝑙𝑑𝑖𝑛𝑔 𝑓𝑢𝑛𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛t_{train,i}=nonlinear\text{ }thresholding\text{ }functionitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n italic_o italic_n italic_l italic_i italic_n italic_e italic_a italic_r italic_t italic_h italic_r italic_e italic_s italic_h italic_o italic_l italic_d italic_i italic_n italic_g italic_f italic_u italic_n italic_c italic_t italic_i italic_o italic_n. In a similar fashion, we also define the test targets 𝐭t⁢e⁢s⁢tsubscript𝐭𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡{\bf t}_{test}bold_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

For categorical hyper-parameters, like activation function (Act), optimizer (Opt), and initialization method (Init), instead of regression loss (Q⁢1)𝑄1(Q1)( italic_Q 1 ), we train a linear perception by minimizing a cross-entropy loss [57]. Here, we also define the targets as detailed above. The only difference here is that the targets have discrete categorical values.

Appendix 4.C Model Zoos Details

In Table 4.C.1, we give an overview of the characteristics for the used model zoos in this paper. This includes

  • •

    The data sets used for zoo creation.

  • •

    The type of the NN models in the zoo.

  • •

    Number of learnable parameters for each of the NNs.

  • •

    Used number of model versions that are taken at the corresponding epochs during training.

  • •

    Total number of NN models contained in the zoo.

In Table 4.C.1 we also compare the existing and the introduced model zoos in prior and this work in terms of properties like initialization, data leakage, and presence of dense model versions obtained by recording the NN model during training evolution.

In Table 4.C.2 we provide the architecture configurations and exact modes of variation of our model zoos.

4.C.1 Zoos Generation Using Tetris Data

As a toy example, we first create 4x4 grey-scaled image data set that we call Tetris by using four tetris shapes. In Figure 4.C.1 we illustrate the basic shapes of the tetris data set. We introduce two zoos, which we call TETRIS-SEED and TETRIS-HYP, which we group under small. Both zoos contain FFN with two layers. In particular, the FFN has an input dimension of 16161616 a latent dimension of 5555, and output dimension of 4444. In total the FFN has 16×5+5×4=1001655410016\times 5+5\times 4=10016 × 5 + 5 × 4 = 100 learnable parameters (see Table 4.C.3). We give an illustration of the used FFN architecture in Figure 4.C.4.

In the TETRIS-SEED zoo, we fix all hyper-parameters and vary only the seed to cover a broad range of the weight space. The TETRIS-SEED zoo contains 1000 models that are trained for 75 epochs. In total, this zoo contains 1000×75=75000100075750001000\times 75=750001000 × 75 = 75000 trained NN weights and biases.

To enrich the diversity of the models, the TETRIS-HYP zoo contains FFNs, which vary in activation function [tanh, relu], the initialization method [uniform, normal, kaiming normal, kaiming uniform, xavier normal, xavier uniform] and the learning rate [1⁢e1𝑒1e1 italic_e-3333, 1⁢e1𝑒1e1 italic_e-4444, 1⁢e1𝑒1e1 italic_e-5555]. In addition, each combination is trained with 100 different seeds. Out of the 3600 models in total, we have successfully trained 2900 for 75 epochs - the remainder crashed and are disregarded. So in total, this zoo contains 2900×75=2175002900752175002900\times 75=2175002900 × 75 = 217500 trained NN weights and biases.

4.C.2 Zoos Generation Using MNIST Data.

Similarly to TETRIS-SEED, we further create medium-sized zoos of CNN models. In total the CNN has 2464 learnable parameters, distributed over 3 convolutional and 2 fully connected layers. The full architecture is detailed in Table 4.C.4. We give an illustration of the used CNN architecture in Figure 4.C.5. Using the MNIST data set, we created five zoos with approximately the same number of CNN models.

In the MNIST-SEED zoo we vary only the random seed (1-1000), while using only one fixed hyper-parameter configuration. In particular,

In MNIST-HYP-1-FIX-SEED we vary the hyper-parameters. We use only one fixed seed for all the hyper-parameter configurations (similarly to [158]). The MNIST-HYP-1-RAND-SEED model zoo contains CNN models, where per each model we draw and use 1 random seed and different hyper-parameter configurations.

We generate MNIST-HYP-5-FIX-SEED ensuring that for each hyper-parameter configuration, we add 5 models that share 5 fixed seeds. We build MNIST-HYP-5-RAND-SEED such that for each hyper-parameter configuration we add 5 models that have different random seeds.

We grouped these model zoos as medium. In total, each of these zoos approximately 1000×25=25000100025250001000\times 25=250001000 × 25 = 25000 trained NN weights and biases.

In Figure 4.C.2 we provide a visualization for different properties of the MNIST-SEED, MNIST-HYP-1-FIX-SEED, MNIST-HYP-1-RANDOM-SEED, MNIST-HYP-5-FIX- SEED and MNIST- HYP-5-RANDOM-SEED zoos. The visualization supports the empirical findings from the paper, that zoos that vary in seed only appear to contain a strong correlation between the mean of the weights and the accuracy. In contrast, the same correlation is considerably lower if the hyper-parameters are varied. Further, we also observe clusters of models with shared initialization methods and activation functions for zoos with fixed seeds. Random seeds seem to disperse these clusters to some degree. This additionally confirms our hypothesis about the importance of the generating factors for the zoos. We find that zoos containing hyper-parameters variation and multiple (random) seeds have a rich set of properties, avoid ’shortcuts’ between the weights (or their statistics) and properties, and therefore benefit hyper-representation learning.

In Figure 4.C.3, we show additional UMAP reductions of MNIST-HYP, which confirm our previous findings. Similarly to the UMAP for the MNIST-HYP-1-FIX-SEED zoo, the UMAP for the MNIST-HYP has distinctive and recognizable initialization points. The categorical hyper-parameters are visually separable in weight space. As we can see in the same figure, it seems that the UMAP for the MNIST-HYP zoo contains very few paths along which the evolution during learning of all the models can be tracked in weight space, facilitating both epoch and accuracy prediction.

4.C.3 Zoo Generation Using F-MNIST Data

We used the F-MNIST data set. As for the previous zoos for the MNIST data set, we have created one zoo with exactly the same number of CNN models as in MNIST-SEED. In this zoo that we call FASHION-SEED, we vary only the random seed (1-1000), while using only one fixed hyper-parameter configuration.

Appendix 4.D Additional Results

In this appendix section, we provide additional results about the impact of the compression ratio c=N/L𝑐𝑁𝐿c=N/Litalic_c = italic_N / italic_L.

4.D.1 Impact of the Compression Ratio N/L

In this subsection, we first explain the experiment setup and then comment on the results about the impact of the compression ratio on the performance for downstream tasks.

Experiment Setup. To see the impact of the compression ratio c=N/L𝑐𝑁𝐿c=N/Litalic_c = italic_N / italic_L on the performance over the downstream tasks, we use our hyper-representation learning approach under different types of architectures, including Ec, ED, and EcD (see Section 3 in the paper). As encoders E and decoders D, we used the attention-base modules introduced in Section 3 in the paper. The attention-based encoder and decoder, on the TETRIS-SEED and TETRIS-HYP zoos, we used 2 attention blocks with 1 attention head each, token dimensions of 128 and FC layers in the attention module of dimension 512.

We use our weight augmentation methods for representation learning (please see Section 3.1 in the paper). We run our representation learning algorithm for up to 2500 epochs, using the adam optimizer [87], a learning rate of 1e-4, weight decay of 1e-9, dropout of 0.1 percent, and batch-sizes of 500. In all of our experiments, we use 70% of the model zoos for training and 15% for validation and testing each. We use checkpoints of all epochs but ensure that samples from the same models are either in the train or in the test split of the zoo. As a quality metric for self-supervised learning, we track the reconstruction R2superscript𝑅2R^{2}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the test split of the zoo.

Results. As Table 4.D.1 shows, all NN architectures decrease in performance, as the compression ratio increases. The purely contrastive setup Ec generally learns embeddings which are useful for the downstream tasks, which are very stable under compression. These results strongly depend on a projection head with enough complexity. The closer the contrastive loss comes to the bottleneck of the encoder, the stronger the downstream tasks suffer under compression. Notably, the reconstruction of ED is very stable, even under high compression ratios. However, higher compression ratios appear to negatively impact the hyper-representations for the downstream tasks we consider here. The combination of reconstruction and contrastive loss shows the best performance for c=2𝑐2c=2italic_c = 2, but suffers under compression. Higher compression ratios perform comparably on the downstream tasks, but don’t manage high reconstruction R2superscript𝑅2R^{2}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We interpret this as sign that the combination of losses requires high capacity bottlenecks. If the capacity is insufficient, the two objectives can’t be both satisfied.

4.D.2 NN Model Characteristics Prediction on FASHION-SEED

Due to space limitations, here in Figure 4.D.2, we present the results on the FASHION-SEED together with the results on MNIST-SEED. The experimental setup is the same as for the MNIST-SEED zoo, which is explained in the paper. Here, we add a complementary result to our ablation study about the seed variation, that we presented in section 4.3 in the paper. Similarly to the discussion in the paper, random seed variation in the FASHION-SEED again appears to make the prediction more challenging. The results show that the proposed approach is on par with the comparing s⁢(W)𝑠𝑊s(W)italic_s ( italic_W ) for this type of model zoo.

4.D.3 In-distribution and Out-of-distribution Prediction

In Figures 4.D.1, 4.D.2 and 4.D.3 we show in-distribution and out-of-distribution comparative results for test accuracy, epoch id, and generalization gap prediction using the MNIST-HYP zoo.

In the majority of the results for accuracy and generalization gap prediction, our learned representations have higher R2superscript𝑅2R^{2}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ score. Also, in the baseline methods the distribution of predicted target values is more dispersed compared to the true target values. On the epoch id prediction we have comparable results but with lower score, we attribute this to the fact that the zoos contain sparse checkpoints and we suspect that there are not enough so that our learning model could capture the present variability. Overall in the in-distribution and out-of-distribution results for test accuracy, epoch id, and generalization gap prediction, the proposed approach has a slight advantage.

Due to space limitations, for the MNIST-SEED, FASHION-SEED zoos and an additional SVHN-SEED zoo we only include out-of-distribution results for accuracy prediction in Figure 4.D.4. Here, too, our learned representations have higher scores in both Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ as well as R2superscript𝑅2R^{2}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Further, the accuracy prediction for SVHN-SEED clearly preserves the order, but has a noticeable bias. We attribute that effect to the different accuracy distributions of MNIST-SEED (ID, accuracy: [0.2,0.95]) and SVHN-SEED (OOD, accuracy: [0.2,0.75]). Due to the higher accuracy in MNIST-SEED, we suspect that the accuracy in SVHN-SEED is overestimated.

Chapter 5 Hyper-Representations as Generative Models: Sampling Unseen Neural Network Weights

This work was accepted for publication at NeurIPS 2022 [145]

Abstract

Learning representations of neural network weights given a model zoo is an emerging and challenging area with many potential applications from model inspection, to neural architecture search or knowledge distillation. Recently, an autoencoder trained on a model zoo was able to learn a hyper-representation, which captures intrinsic and extrinsic properties of the models in the zoo. In this work, we extend hyper-representations for generative use to sample new model weights. We propose layer-wise loss normalization which we demonstrate is key to generate high-performing models and several sampling methods based on the topology of hyper-representations. The models generated using our methods are diverse, performant, and capable of outperforming strong baselines as evaluated on several downstream tasks: initialization, ensemble sampling, and transfer learning. Our results indicate the potential of knowledge aggregation from model zoos to new models via hyper-representations thereby paving the avenue for novel research directions.

5.1 Introduction

Over the last decade, countless neural network models have been trained and uploaded to different model hubs. Many factors such as random initialization and no global optimum ensure that the trained models are different from one another. What could we learn from such a population of neural network models? Since the parameter space of neural networks is complex and high-dimensional, representation learning from such populations (often referred to as model zoos) has become an emerging and challenging area.

Recent work along that direction has demonstrated the ability of such learned representations to capture intrinsic and extrinsic properties of the models in a zoo [158, 144, 116]. According to  [144], NNs populate a low dimensional manifold, which can be learned with an autoencoder via self-supervised learning directly from the model parameters (weights and biases) without access to the original image data and labels. This so-called hyper-representation has been demonstrated to be useful for predicting several model properties such as accuracy, hyperparameters, or architecture configurations.

However,  [144] focused on discriminative downstream tasks by exploiting the encoder only. We take one step further and extend their work towards the generative downstream tasks by sampling model weights directly from the task-agnostic hyper-representation. To that end, we introduce a layer-wise normalization that improves the quality of decoded neural network weights significantly. Based on a careful analysis of the geometry, smoothness, and robustness of this space, we also propose several sampling methods to generate weights in a single forward pass from the hyper-representation. We evaluate our approach on four image datasets and three generative downstream tasks of (i) model initialization, (ii) ensemble sampling, and (iii) transfer learning. Our results demonstrate its capability to outperform previous hyper-representation learning and conventional baselines.

Previous work on generating model weights proposed (Graph) HyperNetworks [62, 177, 89], Bayesian HyperNetworks [37], HyperGANs [140] and HyperTransformers [180] for neural architecture search, model compression, ensembling, transfer- or meta-learning. These methods learn representations by using images and labels of the target domain. In contrast, our approach only uses model weights and does not need access to underlying data samples and labels – an emergent use case, e.g. of deep learning monitoring services or model hubs. In addition to the ability to generate novel and diverse model weights, compared to previous works our approach (a) can generate novel weights conditionally on model zoos from unseen tasks and (b) can be conditioned on the latent factors of the underlying hyper-representation. Notably, both (a) and (b) can be done without the need to retrain hyper-representations.

The results suggest our approach (Figure 5.1.1) to be a promising step towards a general-purpose hyper-representation encapsulating knowledge of model zoos to advance different downstream tasks. The hyper-representations and code to reproduce our results are available at https://github.com/HSG-AIML/NeurIPS_2022-Generative_Hyper_Representations.

5.2 Background: Training Hyper-Representations

We summarize the first stage of our method that corresponds to learning a hyper-representation of a population of neural networks, called a model zoo [144]. In [144] and this paper, a model zoo consists of models trained on the same task such as CIFAR-10 image classification [94]. Specifically, a hyper-representation is learned using an autoencoder 𝐰^i=h⁢(g⁢(𝐰i))subscript^𝐰𝑖ℎ𝑔subscript𝐰𝑖\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i}=h(g(\mathbf{w}_{i}))over^ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h ( italic_g ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) on a zoo of M𝑀Mitalic_M models {𝐰i}1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖1𝑀\{{\bf w}_{i}\}_{1}^{M}{ bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖{\bf w}_{i}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the flattened vector of dimension N𝑁Nitalic_N of all the weights of the i𝑖iitalic_i-th model. The encoder g𝑔gitalic_g compresses vector 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to fixed-size hyper-representation 𝐳i=g⁢(𝐰i)subscript𝐳𝑖𝑔subscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{z}_{i}=g(\mathbf{w}_{i})bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of lower dimension. The decoder hℎhitalic_h decompresses the hyper-representation to the reconstructed vector 𝐰^isubscript^𝐰𝑖\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i}over^ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Both encoder and decoder are built on a self-attention block [159]. The samples from model zoos are understood as sequences of convolutional or fully connected neurons. Each of the neurons is encoded as a token embedding and concatenated to form a sequence. The sequence is passed through several layers of multi-head self-attention. Afterward, a special compression token summarizing the entire sequence is linearly compressed to the bottleneck. The output is fed through a tanh-activation to achieve a bounded latent space 𝐳isubscript𝐳𝑖\mathbf{z}_{i}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the hyper-representation. The decoder is symmetric to the encoder, the embeddings are linearly decompressed from hyper-representations 𝐳isubscript𝐳𝑖\mathbf{z}_{i}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and position encodings are added.

Training is done in a multi-objective fashion, minimizing the composite loss ℒ=β⁢ℒM⁢S⁢E+(1−β)⁢ℒcℒ𝛽subscriptℒ𝑀𝑆𝐸1𝛽subscriptℒ𝑐\mathcal{L}=\beta\mathcal{L}_{MSE}+(1-\beta)\mathcal{L}_{c}caligraphic_L = italic_β caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_S italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_β ) caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ℒcsubscriptℒ𝑐\mathcal{L}_{c}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a contrastive loss and ℒM⁢S⁢Esubscriptℒ𝑀𝑆𝐸\mathcal{L}_{MSE}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_S italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a weight reconstruction loss (see details in [144]). We can write the latter in a layer-wise way to facilitate our discussion in § 5.3.1:

ℒM⁢S⁢E=1M⁢N⁢∑i=1M∑l=1L‖𝐰^i(l)−𝐰i(l)‖22,subscriptℒ𝑀𝑆𝐸1𝑀𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐿subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript^𝐰𝑙𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑙𝑖22\mathcal{L}_{MSE}=\frac{1}{MN}\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{M}\sum\nolimits_{l=1}^{L}||% \hat{\mathbf{w}}^{(l)}_{i}-{\mathbf{w}}^{(l)}_{i}||^{2}_{2},caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_S italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_M italic_N end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | over^ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (5.2.1)

where 𝐰^i(l)subscriptsuperscript^𝐰𝑙𝑖\hat{\mathbf{w}}^{(l)}_{i}over^ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝐰i(l)subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑙𝑖{\mathbf{w}}^{(l)}_{i}bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are reconstructed and original weights for the l𝑙litalic_l-th layer of the i𝑖iitalic_i-th model in the zoo. The contrastive loss ℒcsubscriptℒ𝑐\mathcal{L}_{c}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT leverages two types of data augmentation at train time to impose structure on the latent space: permutation exploiting inherent symmetries of the weight space and random erasing.

5.3 Methods

In the following, we present (i) layer-wise loss normalization to ensure that decoded models are performant, and (ii) sampling methods to generate diverse populations of models.

5.3.1 Layer-Wise Loss Normalization

We observed that hyper-representations as proposed by [144] decode to dysfunctional models, with performance around random guessing. To alleviate that, we propose a novel layer-wise loss normalization (LWLN), which we motivate and detail in the following.

Due to the MSE training loss in (5.2.1), the reconstruction error can generally be expected to be uniformly distributed over all weights and layers of the weight vector 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}bold_w. However, the weight magnitudes of many of our zoos are unevenly distributed across different layers. In these zoos, the even distribution of reconstruction errors leads to undesired effects. Layers with broader distributions and large-magnitude weights are reconstructed well, while layers with narrow distributions and small-magnitude weights are disregarded. The latter layers can become a weak link in the reconstructed models, causing performance to drop significantly down to random guessing. The top row of Figure 5.3.1 shows an example of a baseline hyper-representation learned on the zoo of SVHN models [127]. Common initialization schemes [65, 55] produce distributions with different scaling factors per layer, so the issue is not an artifact of the zoos, but can exist in real-world model populations. Similarly, recent work on generating models normalizes weights to boost performance [89]. In order to achieve equally accurate reconstruction across the layers, we introduce a layer-wise loss normalization (LWLN) with the mean μlsubscript𝜇𝑙\mu_{l}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and standard deviation σlsubscript𝜎𝑙\sigma_{l}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of all weights in layer l𝑙litalic_l estimated over the train split of the zoo:

ℒM⁢S⁢E¯=1M⁢N⁢∑i=1M∑l=1L‖𝐰^i(l)−μlσl−𝐰i(l)−μlσl‖22=1M⁢N⁢∑i=1M∑l=1L‖𝐰^i(l)−𝐰i(l)‖22σl2.subscriptℒ¯𝑀𝑆𝐸1𝑀𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐿superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript^𝐰𝑖𝑙subscript𝜇𝑙subscript𝜎𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑙subscript𝜇𝑙subscript𝜎𝑙221𝑀𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐿superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript^𝐰𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑙22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙2\mathcal{L}_{\bar{MSE}}=\frac{1}{MN}\sum_{i=1}^{M}\sum_{l=1}^{L}\left\|\frac{% \hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i}^{(l)}-\mu_{l}}{\sigma_{l}}-\frac{\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(l)}-\mu% _{l}}{\sigma_{l}}\right\|_{2}^{2}=\frac{1}{MN}\sum_{i=1}^{M}\sum_{l=1}^{L}% \frac{\|\hat{\mathbf{w}}_{i}^{(l)}-\mathbf{w}_{i}^{(l)}\|_{2}^{2}}{\sigma_{l}^% {2}}.caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_M italic_S italic_E end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_M italic_N end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_M italic_N end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG ∥ over^ start_ARG bold_w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (5.3.1)

5.3.2 Sampling from Hyper-Representations

We introduce methods to draw diverse and high-quality samples 𝐳∗∼p⁢(𝐳)similar-tosuperscript𝐳𝑝𝐳\mathbf{z}^{*}\sim p(\mathbf{z})bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_p ( bold_z ) from the learned hyper-representation space to generate model weights 𝐰∗=h⁢(𝐳∗)superscript𝐰ℎsuperscript𝐳\mathbf{w}^{*}=h(\mathbf{z}^{*})bold_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_h ( bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Such sampling is facilitated if there is knowledge on the topology of the space spanned by 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z}bold_z. One way to achieve that is to train a variational autoencoder (VAE) with a predefined prior [88] instead of the autoencoder of  [144]. While training VAEs on common domains such as images has become well-understood and feasible, in our relatively novel weight domain, we found it problematic (see details in Appendix 5.E). Other generative methods avoid a predefined prior of VAEs, either by analyzing the topology of the space learned by the autoencoder or fitting a separate density estimation model on top of the learned representation [108, 61]. These methods assume the representation space to have strong regularities. The hyper-representation space learned by the autoencoder of [144] is already regularized by dropout regularization applied to the encoder and decoder as in [54]. The contrastive loss component requiring similar models to be embedded close to each other may also improve the regularity of the representation space. Empirically, we found our layer-wise loss normalization (LWLN) to further regularize the representation space by ensuring robustness and smoothness (see Figure 5.4.1 in § 5.4).

Given the smoothness and robustness of the learned hyper-representation space, we follow  [108, 61, 54] in estimating the density and topology to draw samples from a regularized autoencoder. To that end, we introduce three strategies to sample from that space: SKDE,SNeigh,SGANsubscript𝑆KDEsubscript𝑆Neighsubscript𝑆GANS_{\text{KDE}},S_{\text{Neigh}},S_{\text{GAN}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KDE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Neigh end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GAN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To model the density and topology in representation space, we use the embeddings of the train set as anchor samples {𝐳i}subscript𝐳𝑖\{\mathbf{z}_{i}\}{ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. We observe that many anchor samples from {𝐳i}subscript𝐳𝑖\{\mathbf{z}_{i}\}{ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } correspond to the models with relatively poor accuracy (Figure 5.3.1), so to improve the quality of sampled weights, we consider the variants of these methods using only those embeddings of training samples corresponding to the top 30% performing models. We denote these sampling methods as SKDE30,SNeigh30,SGAN30subscript𝑆KDE30subscript𝑆Neigh30subscript𝑆GAN30S_{\text{KDE30}},S_{\text{Neigh30}},S_{\text{GAN30}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KDE30 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Neigh30 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GAN30 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively. These methods can potentially decrease sample diversity, however, we found that the generated weights are still diverse enough (e.g. to construct high-performant ensembles, Figure 5.4.3). Finally, as baseline and sanity check we explore sampling uniformly in representation space SUsubscript𝑆𝑈S_{U}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and sampling in low-probability regions SCsubscript𝑆𝐶S_{C}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Uniform SUsubscript𝑆𝑈S_{U}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

As a naive baseline, we draw samples uniformly in hyper-representation space (bounded by tanh, § 5.2) and denote it as SUsubscript𝑆𝑈S_{U}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is naive, because we found that the embeddings 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z}bold_z populate only sections of a shell of a high-dimensional sphere (see Figures 5.D.2 and 5.D.2 in Appendix 5.D). So most of the uniform samples lie in the low-probability regions of the space and are not expected to be decoded to useful models.

Density estimation SKDEsubscript𝑆KDES_{\text{KDE}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KDE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and counterfactual sampling SCsubscript𝑆𝐶S_{C}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

The dimensionality D𝐷Ditalic_D of hyper-representations 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z}bold_z in [144], as well as in our work, is relatively high due to the challenge of compressing weights 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}bold_w. Fitting a probability density model to such a high-dimensional distribution is feasible by making a conditional independence assumption: p⁢(𝐳(j)|𝐳(k),𝐰)=p⁢(𝐳(j)|𝐰)𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝐳𝑗superscript𝐳𝑘𝐰𝑝conditionalsuperscript𝐳𝑗𝐰p(\mathbf{z}^{(j)}|\mathbf{z}^{(k)},\mathbf{w})=p(\mathbf{z}^{(j)}|\mathbf{w})italic_p ( bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_w ) = italic_p ( bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_w ), where 𝐳(j)superscript𝐳𝑗\mathbf{z}^{(j)}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the j𝑗jitalic_j-th dimensionality of the embedding 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z}bold_z. To model the distribution of each j𝑗jitalic_j-th dimensionality, we choose kernel density estimation (KDE), as it is a powerful yet simple, non-parametric, and deterministic method with a single hyperparameter. We fit a KDE to the M𝑀Mitalic_M anchor samples {𝐳i(j)}i=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐳𝑖𝑗𝑖1𝑀\{\mathbf{z}_{i}^{(j)}\}_{i=1}^{M}{ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of each dimension j𝑗jitalic_j, and draw samples z(j)superscript𝑧𝑗z^{(j)}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from that distribution: z(j)∼p⁢(𝐳(j))=1M⁢h⁢∑i=1MK⁢(𝐳(j)−𝐳i(j)h)similar-tosuperscript𝑧𝑗𝑝superscript𝐳𝑗1𝑀ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀𝐾superscript𝐳𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐳𝑗𝑖ℎz^{(j)}\sim p(\mathbf{z}^{(j)})=\frac{1}{Mh}\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{M}K(\frac{% \mathbf{z}^{(j)}-\mathbf{z}^{(j)}_{i}}{h})italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_p ( bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_M italic_h end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K ( divide start_ARG bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_h end_ARG ), where K⁢(x)=(2⁢π)−1/2⁢exp⁡(−x22)𝐾𝑥superscript2𝜋12superscript𝑥22K(x)=(2\pi)^{-1/2}\exp{(-\frac{x^{2}}{2})}italic_K ( italic_x ) = ( 2 italic_π ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) is the Gaussian kernel and hℎhitalic_h is a bandwidth hyperparameter. The samples of each dimension z(j)superscript𝑧𝑗z^{(j)}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are concatenated to form samples 𝐳∗=[z(1),z(2),⋯,z(D)]superscript𝐳superscript𝑧1superscript𝑧2⋯superscript𝑧𝐷\mathbf{z}^{*}=[z^{(1)},z^{(2)},\cdots,z^{(D)}]bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_D ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]. This method is denoted as SKDEsubscript𝑆KDES_{\text{KDE}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KDE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

As a sanity check, we invert the SKDEsubscript𝑆KDES_{\text{KDE}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT KDE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT method and explicitly draw samples from regions not populated by anchor samples, i.e. with a low probability according to the KDE. This method, denoted as SCsubscript𝑆𝐶S_{C}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, essentially samples counterfactual embeddings and similarly to SUsubscript𝑆𝑈S_{U}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is expected to perform poorly.

Neighbor sampling SNeighsubscript𝑆NeighS_{\text{Neigh}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Neigh end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

Sampling neighbors of anchor samples {𝐳i}subscript𝐳𝑖\{\mathbf{z}_{i}\}{ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } could be a simple and effective sampling strategy, but due to the high sparsity of the hyper-representation space, this strategy results in poor-quality samples.
